review.title: A General Framework for Density Based Time Series Clustering Exploiting a Novel Admissible Pruning Strategy
review.abstract: Time Series Clustering is an important subroutine in many higher-level data mining analyses, including data editing for classifiers, summarization, and outlier detection. It is well known that for similarity search the superiority of Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) over Euclidean distance gradually diminishes as we consider ever larger datasets. However, as we shall show, the same is not true for clustering. Clustering time series under DTW remains a computationally expensive operation. In this work, we address this issue in two ways. We propose a novel pruning strategy that exploits both the upper and lower bounds to prune off a very large fraction of the expensive distance calculations. This pruning strategy is admissible and gives us provably identical results to the brute force algorithm, but is at least an order of magnitude faster. For datasets where even this level of speedup is inadequate, we show that we can use a simple heuristic to order the unavoidable calculations in a most-useful-first ordering, thus casting the clustering into an anytime framework. We demonstrate the utility of our ideas with both single and multidimensional case studies in the domains of astronomy, speech physiology, medicine and entomology. In addition, we show the generality of our clustering framework to other domains by efficiently obtaining semantically significant clusters in protein sequences using the Edit Distance, the discrete data analogue of DTW.

metadata.title: A General Framework for Density Based Time Series Clustering Exploiting a Novel Admissible Pruning Strategy

sections.text: It is well known that when looking for similarities, the superiority of Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) over Euclidean distance gradually diminishes as we look at larger and larger data sets. However, as we will show, this does not apply to clustering. Clustering time series under DTW remains a mathematically expensive process. In this paper, we approach this problem in two ways. We propose a novel circumcision strategy that exploits both the upper and lower limits to cut off a very large portion of the expensive distance calculations. This circumcision strategy is permissible and has been shown to provide identical results to the raw force algorithm, but is at least an order of magnitude faster. For data sets where even this level of acceleration is insufficient, we show that we can apply a simple heuristic strategy to order the inevitable calculations in a most useful first order.

For most data mining algorithms of time series, the quality of the results depends almost exclusively on the distance measure used [49]. In the last ten years, a consensus has emerged that the DTW distance measure is the best measure in most areas and almost always exceeds the Euclidean distance (ED) and other alleged rivals [49]. As a concrete example, we consider the two clusters of three randomly selected mammals shown in Fig. 2. The input data is mitochondrial DNA after it has been converted into a time series representation (the conversion of DNA into time series is a commonly used operation [40] [41]). Two types of DNA mutations, insertions and deletions have the effect of "warping" the time series. At least in this case, we can see that these mutations (and mutations) are uncommon.

sections.heading: 1.1 Why This Problem Is Hard
sections.text: Since the DTW is intrinsically slow due to its quadratic complexity of time, there are two ideas that are commonly used to mitigate the problem of using such a slow distance measurement [41]. We discuss them here only to dismiss them as possible solutions. However, the convergence of DTW and Euclidean distances means that for many problems, including the discovery of motives [35] and classification [49], the results of DTW and Euclidean distances tend to become increasingly similar as the datasets grow larger, suggesting that it is more efficient to use the distance of euclides to collect large datasets. Increasing effectiveness of lower datasets increases.

sections.heading: 1.2 Why Existing Work Is Not the Answer
sections.text: In general, many cluster algorithms achieve scalability by using a spatial access method. For example, the scalable version of the ubiquitous DBSCAN uses an R * tree [12]. However, because DTW is not a metric, it is very difficult to index it, especially for long (i.e., high-dimensional) time series objects. Beyond the need to support DTW scalable, we note the need for a cluster algorithm that supports inventory against outliers. That is, unlike some cluster methods that attempt to explain all the data, we believe that it is particularly important to enable a time series cluster algorithms that ignore some data. Consider the example in Fig. 4. We took twelve objects from a heraldic shield dataset that we group with k-means and DP.

sections.heading: 3 BACKGROUND
sections.text: This problem is typically based on cost-effective distance measurements, but expensive disk access [6]. However, the problem we want to solve is DTW, which is itself a very expensive distance measurement. In situations where even the data can be stored in main memory, the time needed to cluster can be in the order of days / weeks. So the problem we are interested in is that the CPU is limited, not the I / O.

sections.heading: 3.1 Anytime Algorithms
sections.text: For most clustering algorithms, it is well known that not all distance measurements contribute equally to the final clustering mapping. For example, a recent paper on hierarchical clustering shows (under some mild assumptions) that it is possible to capture the true structure of clustering using just carefully selected O (n log2 n) distance calculations [28]. The fact that some distance calculations are more important than others immediately suggests that we should use algorithms at all times, provided that we can find only an efficient and (even somewhat) effective test to identify these influential distance calculations. Remember that algorithms are algorithms that can provide a valid solution to a problem even if they are interrupted before they are finished [60] [61]. Starting with a negligible amount of set-up time, these algorithms always have the best response available, and the quality of the response improves as the execution time increases.

sections.heading: 4 ALGORITHM
sections.text: We start with the review of the basic algorithm, which we will expand and specialize in order to deal with DTW.

sections.heading: 4.1 Density Peaks Algorithm Overview
sections.text: We have decided to expand the DP framework to address major time series clustering problems because not only do the following points mean that abnormal objects themselves cannot be clustered, but the presence of these objects can affect the labels of objects that can be clustered in unpredictable ways. DP algorithms have shown that they are capable of ignoring abnormal data points. DP algorithms are able to handle datasets whose clusters can form arbitrary shapes, in contrast to kmeans and related algorithms that assume that the clusters are "spheres" in space. This observation is particularly important for DTW, which is not a metric.

sections.heading: 4.2.3 Multidimensional Time Series Clustering
sections.text: While most research efforts in the field of time series clustering only looked at the one-dimensional case [23], the increasing prevalence of medical sensors (c.f. Section 6.2) and portable devices (c.f. Section 6) has highlighted the need to support multi-dimensional clustering. Fortunately, our extension of TadPoles to the multi-dimensional case requires that only a single line of code is changed. To provide clarity, we highlight these changes for multi-dimensional clustering on TABLE 8 and TABLE 9.

sections.heading: 4.2.5 Distance-Computation Ordering Heuristic
sections.text: If we remember that the DP algorithm by definition does not have access to class labels, the basic principle is to calculate the local density (TABLE 1) and then locate the NN distances from the higher density lists (TABLE 2) of the objects. Only the latter step is acceptable at any time; however, the first step can be considered setup time [3] [60]. Before attempting to create an oracle order function, it will be instructive to look at two baselines: What is the best thing we could do, and what would we have to do to claim that we beat the most obvious straws? The best order we consider heuristic is an oracle order. We can calculate this by cheating the algorithm. At each step of the algorithm, this order chooses the object that maximizes the current edge index. The algorithm cheats because a clustering algorithm does not normally have access to class labels.

sections.heading: 5 EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it has never come as far as it has this year.

sections.heading: 5.2 Parameter Sensitivity Experiments
sections.text: In order to show that TADPole is not sensitive to parameter settings, we took the symbol and insect dataset [25] and performed TADPole with k = 6 and k = 11, respectively. We then varied the parameter of limit distances (dc) and measured the margin index determined with the alternative settings. As we can see from Fig. 14. (a) and (b), there is a very wide range of choices for the values of dc, resulting in high-quality clustering. We performed the same experiment for several other datasets (see [64] for details), and the results confirm our claim that TADPole is not sensitive to these limit parameters. Despite this finding, it is clearly desirable to have instructions for parameter setting. In the next section, we will present such heuristics.

sections.heading: 5.3 Heuristic for Setting Parameters

We illustrate our results in Fig. 15. From Fig. 15, we can see that the value obtained for various distorting window widths closely matches the corresponding Edge Index for a fixed DC. As long as the distorting window width remains in a relatively high range, we can consider the parameter selection to be good. At this point, we are now able to answer the following question: If the distortion window width is reasonably well set, how do we estimate dc? sections.heading: 6 CASE STUDIES
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1 Electromagnetic Articulograph Dataset
sections.text: The device consists of a series of inconspicuous accelerometers attached to multiple locations on the tongue, lips, jaw, nose, and forehead that can record high-resolution 3D motion data in real time. Recent research suggests that articulators ultimately enable "silent speech" that transmits non-acoustic articulation data to speech, an idea that has significant potential for facilitating oral communication after laryngectomy. [55] The most common use of articulators is speech therapy for a variety of speech disorders, but there is a significant barrier to using the system, which can take up to 30 minutes.

sections.heading: 6.2 Pulsus Dataset
sections.text: Pulsus paradox is defined as a significant decrease in pulse with inspiration. It is a symptom of cardiac tamponade, a life-threatening condition in which high pressure fluid fills the sac around the heart, impairing heart filling and causing 20,000 deaths per year in the U.S. alone. Of the various ways to detect pulse, the least invasive and simplest uses the PPG (PhotoPlethysmogram) shown in Fig. 18.top. For this case study, we consider a data set of 500 PPGs from two sources: the MIMIC II Waveform Database [16] [46] and our collaborators. The latter data set has the advantage of having our collaborators follow-up the patients (in some cases, post-mortem); therefore, we have access to unusually rich annotations and external knowledge to evaluate our findings. As shown in Fig. 18.top, the raw PPG data is very complex and we have converted the UCLA School of Medicine to Dr. John Criley's suggestions.

sections.heading: 6.3 Person Re-Identification Dataset
sections.text: As shown in Fig. 20, we can extract colored histograms from the video and thus treat the problem as a multidimensional time series problem. We looked at the PRID dataset [20] by randomly extracting 1,000 images from 12 different individuals. After using TADPoles in this dataset to cluster the images of these 12 individuals, we reached an edge index of 95.4% and a distance cut-off of 80% (at any time at [64]). In contrast, the Euclidean distance only reaches an edge index of 89%.

sections.heading: 6.4 Clustering Multidimensional Data
sections.text: To demonstrate the suitability of TADPole for multidimensional data, we have bundled two real-world datasets - Cricket and uWaveGesture.

sections.heading: 6.4.2 uWaveGestureLibrary Dataset
sections.text: For this experiment, we look at the three-dimensional uWaveGesture Library dataset [25], which was collected to support efficient personalized gesture recognition on a variety of electronic and mobile devices. This dataset contains eight simple gestures identified by a Nokia study, collected from eight participants using the Wii prototype. Fig. 22 shows these gestures as the paths of hand movement [31] [38].In this experiment, as before, we are interested in the feasibility of TADPoles for clustering human gestures. We use all eight gestures as input to TADPoles. The number of objects in this dataset is 896, with each of the time series having a length of 315 seconds and a sampling rate of 100 Hz. After running TADPoles on this data, we reach an edge index of 0.93 with an average of about 88%. In wall clock times, TADPoles takes only 56 seconds to cluster these 47 minutes of data.

sections.heading: 6.5 Generalizing TADPole to Cluster Discrete Data
sections.text: The interested reader may wonder if this framework is general enough to extend it to other types of data. In this section, we present a discussion about generalizing this framework to cluster very long discrete biological sequences. We note at this point that our experiments do not claim a novel discovery of biological significance. We are merely demonstrating a proof-of-concept that the TADPole framework can be expanded to perform rapid clustering of long biological strings. More generally, we believe that this example shows that the TADPole framework can be useful for clustering for any distance measurement for which both upper and lower limits can be calculated. Beyond the DTW, this would include most string similarity measurements (as we show below), Earth Movers Distance, Graph Edit Distance, etc.

sections.heading: 6.5.1 Clustering of Protein Sequences with Edit Distance
sections.text: This year it is as far as never before in the history of the Federal Republic of Germany.

sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: By introducing novel pruning strategies that exploit both upper and lower boundaries, we have developed a robust DTW cluster algorithm that is both absolutely much faster than the state-of-the-art algorithms and capable of calculating clustering at any time. We have demonstrated the usefulness of our algorithms in various areas, including two where our algorithm is currently actively used (EMA and Pulsus), and we have made all of our code and data publicly available so that the community can leverage and expand our ideas.

sections.heading: 8 ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: We would like to thank NSF IIS-1161997 II, NIH R03 DC013990, NIH R01 DC013547 and all donors of the datasets for their financial support of our research. We would also like to thank Dr. John Criley (UCLA School of Medicine) for donating the PPG data and for the detailed explanation of the subtleties of Pulsus Paradoxus.STRATEGY 17

It has been extensively shown in the literature that the 40-year old distance DTW is an ideal similarity measure to capture/be invariant to such out-of-sync relationships [47].
For most time series data mining algorithms, the quality of the output depends almost exclusively on the distance measure used [49].
In the last decade, a consensus has emerged that the DTW distance measure is the best measure in most domains, almost always outperforming the Euclidean Distance (ED) and other purported rivals [49].

1 Why This Problem Is Hard Because DTW is intrinsically slow due to its quadratic time complexity, there are two ideas that are commonly used to mitigate the problem of using such a sluggish distance measure [41].

It has been noted that for many problems, including motif discovery [35] and classification [49], the results returned by DTW and Euclidean distance tend to become increasingly similar as the dataset sizes increase.

The effectiveness of this lowerbounding tends to improve dramatically as the datasets get larger [41].

We adapt DP (Density Peaks), a relatively new clustering framework that is able to ignore outlying data points [45].

We augment DP such that it can exploit both DTW upper and lower bounds to compute only the absolutely necessary DTW calculations, and do so in a best-first manner, giving our algorithm the desirable anytime algorithm behavior [3][61].

Recall that anytime algorithms are algorithms that can return a valid solution to a problem, even if interrupted before ending [60][61].
Recall that anytime algorithms are algorithms that can return a valid solution to a problem, even if interrupted before ending [60][61].
The desirable properties of anytime algorithms are interruptibility, monotonicity, measurable quality, diminishing returns, preemptibility, and low overhead [61].
Note that this is a very brief introduction to anytime algorithms; we refer the interested reader to [61], which contains an excellent survey.

1 Electromagnetic Articulograph Dataset The Electromagnetic Articulograph (EMA) is a device that is increasingly used for mouth movement studies [55].

Recent research has suggested that articulographs may eventually allow a “silent speech” interface that translates non-audio articulatory data to speech output, an idea that has significant potential for facilitating oral communication after a laryngectomy [55].
We consider a dataset of lower-lip accelerometer time series movement data of 18 words collected from multiple speakers, for a total of 414 objects [56].
The amount of distance pruning achieved by TADPole is ~94% for the Articulographs [55].

1 Clustering of Protein Sequences with Edit Distance The identification of biological sequences with similar functionality requires similarity search in large databases, and is a well-known problem in the Bioinformatics community [14][19].

1 Clustering of Protein Sequences with Edit Distance The identification of biological sequences with similar functionality requires similarity search in large databases, and is a well-known problem in the Bioinformatics community [14][19].
Typically these protein strings are very long, therefore similarity search in such a large sequence database can be computationally challenging [2].
In order to measure the similarity between two sequences of biological strings, researchers often use Edit Distance (EdD), or one of its many variants [29].

As an example, for two strings A = ‘INDUSTRY’ and B = ‘INTEREST’, the optimal set of editing operations for T(A,B) are: Starting string = INDUSTRY, Goal String = INTEREST S(A[3],B[3]) = INT(D)USTRY S(A[4],B[4]) = INTE(U)STRY I(5,B[5]) = INTERSTRY I(6,B[6]) = INTERESTRY D(A[9],-) = INTEREST-(R)Y D(A[9],-) = INTEREST-(Y) Therefore EdD(A,B) = 6.

Both edit distance and DTW are elastic distance measures [9] and for both of these measures, tight lower and upper bounds are already defined.
As the lower bound of the edit distance, we use a notion of the distance that maps the strings of the database onto a multidimensional integer space using a wavelet based method [22].
In order to demonstrate the utility of TADPole in accelerating the clustering of large protein sequences, we use a random chunk of in [27] of the UniProt dataset [54].

metadata.abstractText: Time Series Clustering is an important subroutine in many higher-level data mining analyses, including data editing for classifiers, summarization, and outlier detection. It is well known that for similarity search the superiority of Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) over Euclidean distance gradually diminishes as we consider ever larger datasets. However, as we shall show, the same is not true for clustering. Clustering time series under DTW remains a computationally expensive operation. In this work, we address this issue in two ways. We propose a novel pruning strategy that exploits both the upper and lower bounds to prune off a very large fraction of the expensive distance calculations. This pruning strategy is admissible and gives us provably identical results to the brute force algorithm, but is at least an order of magnitude faster. For datasets where even this level of speedup is inadequate, we show that we can use a simple heuristic to order the unavoidable calculations in a most-useful-first ordering, thus casting the clustering into an anytime framework. We demonstrate the utility of our ideas with both single and multidimensional case studies in the domains of astronomy, speech physiology, medicine and entomology. In addition, we show the generality of our clustering framework to other domains by efficiently obtaining semantically significant clusters in protein sequences using the Edit Distance, the discrete data analogue of DTW.
metadata.creator: Microsoft® Office Word 2007
